# Introduction

- The role of roots’ chemical composition in determining SOM persistence remains uncertain. 
  
- Suberin---a hydrophobic, carbon-rich biopolymer found in root cell walls---has been hypothesized to enhance long-term soil carbon storage
  
- OM-stability paradigms emphasize microbial and mineral interactions over intrinsic biochemical recalcitrance.
  
This study investigates how varying suberin content influences mineralization rates and chemical transformations of root-derived organic matter in soil. 

# Methods
Using ¹³C-labeled roots spanning a natural suberin gradient, we tracked decomposition in both intact pots and litterbag microcosms over 30--40 weeks.

# Results
 - CO₂ flux from jars not correlated with suberin content
  
 - The proportion of simple plant compounds decreased over time while complex plant and microbial compounds increased except for the high-suberin treatment (soy)

# Conclusion
By integrating ¹³C tracers with molecular characterizations, this work advances a mechanistic understanding of soil carbon cycling at the root–soil interface by quantifying the partitioning of root-derived carbon between incorporation into SOM and mineralization to CO₂. Linking root chemistry variation to SOM dynamics can inform plant breeding programs and trait-based ecosystem management efforts aimed at enhancing long-term soil carbon stability.
